Coetzee Awarded Nobel Prize for Literature

Roger Wilkison

South African writer JM Coetzee has won this year's Nobel Prize for Literature. The Swedish Academy, which awarded the prize, praised Mr. Coetzee's works for what it called theirwell-craftedï¼ææå·§å¦ï¼composition and analytical brilliance.

But the publicity-shy author has long been skittish about the attention of the media and stayed away from the awards ceremony on both occasions.

Mr. Coetzee's main characters are often innocents oroutcastsï¼è¢«éå¼çï¼who are overwhelmed by historical forces over which they have no influence. South Africa's formerapartheidï¼ç§æéç¦»ï¼system of separating the races is a recurring theme in his works.

The Swedish Academy praised Mr. Coetzee for his intellectual honesty, noting that the 63-year-old author has been, in its words, ruthless in his criticism of the cruel rationalism and cosmetic morality in western civilization.
